unnormalised: I am frequently asked about the various identifiers used in banking and financial transactions in India. It can be confusing, so I'll try to clarify some key ones. For example, you often encounter the term "IFSC Code." This is an 11-character alphanumeric code (e.g., SBIN0001234) used to identify bank branches for electronic fund transfers like NEFT, RTGS, and IMPS. It's crucial for ensuring the money goes to the correct destination. You can usually find the IFSC code on your cheque book or bank statement.
normalised: I am frequently asked about the various identifiers used in banking and financial transactions in India. It can be confusing, so I will try to clarify some key ones. For example, you often encounter the term "I-F-S-C Code." This is an eleven-character alphanumeric code (e.g., S-B-I-N zero zero zero one two three four) used to identify bank branches for electronic fund transfers like N-E-F-T, R-T-G-S, and I-M-P-S. It is crucial for ensuring the money goes to the correct destination. You can usually find the I-F-S-C code on your cheque book or bank statement.

unnormalised: Another important identifier is the "MICR Code." This is a 9-digit code printed on the cheque leaf (e.g., 400006001). It stands for Magnetic Ink Character Recognition code and is used for faster processing of cheques. The first 3 digits represent the city code, the next 3 represent the bank code, and the last 3 represent the branch code. You'll also come across "Account Numbers", typically 11 to 16 digits long (e.g., 1234567890123456), unique to each account holder within a bank.
normalised: Another important identifier is the "M-I-C-R Code." This is a nine-digit code printed on the cheque leaf (e.g., four hundred thousand and six thousand and one). It stands for Magnetic Ink Character Recognition code and is used for faster processing of cheques. The first three digits represent the city code, the next three represent the bank code, and the last three represent the branch code. You will also come across "Account Numbers", typically eleven to sixteen digits long (e.g., one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two three four five six), unique to each account holder within a bank.

unnormalised: Finally, PAN (Permanent Account Number) is a 10-character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department (e.g., ABCDE1234F). While not exclusively a banking identifier, it's mandatory for many financial transactions, particularly those exceeding Rs. 50,000, and is linked to your CIBIL score. Always ensure you provide the correct identifiers to avoid any delays or complications in your transactions.
normalised: Finally, P-A-N (Permanent Account Number) is a ten-character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department (e.g., A-B-C-D-E one two three four F). While not exclusively a banking identifier, it is mandatory for many financial transactions, particularly those exceeding rupees fifty thousand, and is linked to your C-I-B-I-L score. Always ensure you provide the correct identifiers to avoid any delays or complications in your transactions.
